title: 108_s1431
content: The Act titled "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2003" defines key terms. The Act titled "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2003" defines the term 'semiautomatic assault weapon' as including specific rifles such as AK-47, AR-15, and HK-91 among others. The Act "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2003" lists various semiautomatic assault weapons, including M1 Carbine, Saiga, SAR-8, SKS with detachable magazine, SLG 95, SLR 95, Steyr AUG, Sturm, Ruger Mini-14, Tavor, Thompson 1927, Uzi, Calico M-110, MAC-10, Olympic Arms OA, TEC-9, and Uzi. The curr_chunk lists specific criteria for semiautomatic rifles and shotguns that are considered assault weapons, including features like detachable magazines, folding or telescoping stocks, threaded barrels, pistol grips, forward grips, and barrel shrouds. It also mentions restrictions on rifles with fixed magazines that can hold more than 10 rounds. The curr_chunk outlines criteria for semiautomatic pistols, rifles, and shotguns classified as assault weapons based on features like detachable magazines, pistol grips, threaded barrels, and fixed magazine capacities. The curr_chunk details additional criteria for classifying firearms as assault weapons, including revolving cylinder shotguns, frames or receivers similar to specified firearms, conversion kits, and military or law enforcement-designed firearms not suitable for sporting purposes. The curr_chunk introduces definitions for "barrel shroud" and "conversion kit" in relation to firearms, specifying their characteristics and purposes. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to firearms, such as detachable magazine, fixed magazine, folding or telescoping stock, forward grip, and pistol grip. These definitions help clarify the characteristics and functions of different firearm components. The curr_chunk defines "pistol grip" as a grip or thumbhole stock that can function as a grip, and "threaded barrel" as a feature designed to allow attachment of a firearm. SEC. 3 amends the Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Protection Act by eliminating the sunset provision. SEC. 4 modifies the grandfather provisions in the United States Code regarding firearms possession. SEC. 5 involves the repeal of certain exemptions. SEC. 5 amends Section 922(v)(3) of title 18, United States Code, by specifying that certain exemptions do not apply to manually operated firearms, permanently inoperable firearms, or antique firearms. Section 922(v) of title 18, United States Code is amended to prohibit the transfer of semiautomatic assault weapons except through licensed dealers or law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General is required to maintain records of these weapons. The Attorney General must maintain records of any semiautomatic assault weapon used in a crime and submit an annual report to Congress. SEC. 7 strengthens the ban on large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 7 strengthens the ban on transfer of semiautomatic assault weapons with large capacity ammunition feeding devices, imposing penalties for violations. Additionally, a certification requirement is added for firearms imported into the United States. The text amends regulations regarding the transfer of large capacity ammunition feeding devices manufactured before September 13, 1994, requiring certification to the Attorney General within 60 days of transfer. The text amends penalties for knowingly violating regulations on large capacity ammunition feeding devices manufactured before September 13, 1994. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. SEC. 8 amends Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code to include semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices in unlawful weapons transfers to juveniles. SEC. 9 imposes a ban on the importation of large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 9 imposes a ban on importing large capacity ammunition feeding devices into the United States.
